2025 was Aave's best year ever.

Here's the story: 
In 2025, Aave became DeFi's biggest protocol.

It peaked at $75 billion deposits, more than any other protocol in DeFi history. 
DeFi dominance also grew from 17% to 29%. That means one-third of all DeFi TVL is on Aave. 
In the lending sector, dominance is even higher. Aave is larger than every other competitor combined. 
In 2025, "trillions" was more than a meme as the protocol crossed $3 trillion in all-time assets supplied. 
Aave's multi-chain strategy thrived as it became the first DeFi protocol to reach $1 billion TVL across six networks simultaneously. 
Aave was the default destination for the most in-demand onchain assets, providing billions in liquidity. 
Most impressively, at its peak TVL, the protocol would rank among the top 50 U.S. banks by size. 
The Aave effect was on full display in 2025, helping partners like @ethena_labs, @maplefinance, @Ripple, and @Plasma grow to billions. 
USDe by @ethena_labs was one of 2025â€™s fastest-growing stablecoins,  fueled by its native yield and the Aavethena partnership.

At peak, Aave held over 50% of Ethena's stablecoin supply through USDe, sUSDe, and sUSDe @pendle_fi PTs. 
syrupUSDT by @maplefinance debuted on Aave in Q4 2025. By the end of the year, over 70% of the supply was earning yield in the @plasma and @ethereum Core markets. 
Stables that bet on Aave thrive. @ripple's RLUSD grew from $250 million circulating supply to $1.3 billion after onboarding to the @ethereum Core market and Horizon. 
The Aave effect isnâ€™t just for assets, it's for networks too. When @plasma launched last September, it attracted $1.3 billion in the first hour.

Just 48 hours later, deposits reached $6.6 billion. 
In 2025, embedded DeFi was the leading trend, with partners ranging from LatAm consumer apps to embedded wallet infrastructure, all supporting Aave. 
One of Aave's core business lines, @GHO, also had quite a year, tripling its total supply throughout 2025. 
Horizon, Aave's RWA market, became the largest and fastest-growing venue for RWA-backed loans in DeFi in less than 6 months. 
One of the most significant DeFi announcements of the year was Aave App, a consumer-focused mobile savings app powered by the Aave protocol. 
Last but not least, after two years of development, Aave V4 was deployed on the testnet.

It introduces a new architecture, allowing Aave to expand beyond onchain collateral and paving the way for new DeFi lending use cases.

V4 will launch on mainnet in 2026. 
As we kick off 2026, Aave is uniquely positioned to bring the next trillion dollars and millions of users onchain through Aave V4, Horizon, and the Aave App. 
We'd like to extend a massive thank you DAO service providers, delegates, partners, users, and the rest of the Aave ecosystem for their contributions last year.

Aave will win. 
Read the full recap here: https://aave.com/blog/aave-2025-recap

Today was a textbook â€œno-bid + liquidation cascadeâ€ day, with downside exaggerated by thin liquidity. Rather than calling it a definitive structural bear regime, itâ€™s more accurate to frame it as a return to leverage-dominant price discovery after a macro-driven shock. Key watchpoints today: Can BTC reclaim and hold ~$84Kâ€“$85K? Do ETF flows improve (and does BTC continue to lag ETH/SOL)? Is OI rebuild â€œhealthy resetâ€ or â€œfuel for the next liquidationâ€? Which Platforms Are Best for Trading Standard Crypto Tokens?

Introduction

In 2026, most traders rely on centralized exchanges to trade major cryptocurrencies like  $BTC ,  $ETH , and Solana, due to their strong liquidity, security, efficient execution, and fiat access. Platforms such as Bitget, Coinbase, Binance, KuCoin, Bybit, MEXC, and Kraken remain popular, each catering to different trading needs and experience levels.

Why  do traders use centralized exchanges for standard tokens ?

Centralized exchanges stand out by providing strong liquidity, quick trade execution, and easy access to fiat, which is crucial for high-volume, frequently traded tokens. They also enhance safety for traders through account protections, customer support, and regulatory compliance.

Bitget combines low fees, strong security, compliance, and diverse trading options in a single platform.

Coinbase is known for compliance, broad token support, and beginner-to-advanced trading options.

Binance offers deep liquidity, a wide range of products, and competitive fees for high-volume traders.

KuCoin emphasizes asset diversity and global access, offering both standard tokens and a wide range of alternative cryptocurrencies.

Bybit offers spot and derivatives trading with fast execution and advanced tools, appealing to active, performance-focused traders.

MEXC offers low fees, frequent new listings, and supports both standard and emerging tokens, appealing to traders seeking diverse market options.

Kraken is a long-established, secure, and compliant exchange supporting standard tokens with fiat integration, favored by institutions despite higher fees for its reliability and transparency.

Conclusion 

Centralized exchanges dominate standard crypto trading, with platforms like Bitget, Coinbase, and Binance catering to different priorities. Bitget stands out for its low fees, strong security, broad accessibility, and support for all trader levels.

ğŸ‡ºğŸ‡¸US crypto rules took a meaningful step forward yesterday. 

The Senate Agriculture Committee advanced the Digital Commodity Intermediaries Act on a 12-11 party-line vote â€” the first crypto market-structure bill to ever pass out of any Senate committee.ğŸ§µ
2/ The legislation gives the CFTC primary authority over spot digital commodity markets (Bitcoin, Ethereum, and similar assets). 

It sets up registration, oversight, and consumer protection rules for crypto exchanges, brokers, and dealers â€” building straight off the House CLARITY Act.
3/ Senate Ag Chair Boozman described it as the key move needed to protect users while keeping American crypto innovation competitive. CFTC Chair Selig welcomed the progress.

Democrats voted no, pointing to missing stronger fraud protections, political profiteering rules, and unresolved stablecoin issues.
4/ The critical next step is the Senate Banking Committee. They must pass their own version of the bill (which is expected to be much tougher due to heavy bank lobbying, especially around stablecoins). 

Only after Banking acts can the two versions be merged and sent to the full Senate for a final vote â€” where bipartisan support (at least 60 votes) will be required.
5/5 Meanwhile, on the same day SEC Chair Paul Atkins and CFTC Chair Michael Selig held a joint event and relaunched Project Crypto as a full SEC-CFTC collaboration. 

Focus areas include clearer asset classification, cutting overlapping compliance, defining jurisdictional lines, and enabling tokenized collateral, perpetual futures, and onshore prediction markets.

The direction is clear: structured, pro-innovation US crypto rules are gaining speed in 2026 â€” but everything now depends on whether the Banking Committee moves forward.
